mission.title: Censored Planet Lab
mission.description: We are a team of researchers in the Computer Science and Engineering department at the University of Michigan working to build scalable systems and novel techniques to protect users’ Internet experiences from censorship, surveillance, and digital divide.

research.name: Monitoring Censorship at Global Scale
research.description: We monitor network interference and disruptions globally to identify and understand censorship trends across countries.

research.name: Exposing Emerging Censorship Threats
research.description: We investigate new and evolving techniques used to suppress access to information and restrict online freedom.

research.name: Characterizing Internet Splintering
research.description: We study the fragmentation of the global Internet and how nation-level policies impact access and connectivity.

research.name: Evaluating Network Middlebox Deployments
research.description: We study the deployment and behavior of network middleboxes to assess their role in censorship and surveillance.

research.name: Advancing Traffic Obfuscation Against Novel Fingerprinting Attacks
research.description: We develop novel obfuscation methods to evade censorship and ensure secure, anonymous communication online.

research.name: Securing VPN and Circumvention Tool Ecosystem
research.description: We assess VPNs and circumvention tools for reliability and security, and help improve their resistance to blocking.

lab_updates.tagline: Diwen Xue received Rackham Predoctoral Fellowship for his work on measuring and enhancing the security, privacy, and availability of the Internet.
Diwen Xue received the Towner Prize for Distinguished Academic Achievement.
Our work “Digital Discrimination of Users in Sanctioned States: The Case of the Cuba Embargo” won a Distinguished Paper award in Usenix Security 2024.
We presented four papers at Usenix Security 2024.
Our work “Network Measurement Methods for Locating and Examining Censorship Devices” won the IRTF Applied Networking Research Prize.
Prof. Roya Ensafi received the NSF CAREER Award to advance the scientific understanding of contemporary online censorship and develop principled and effective countermeasures.
Prof. Roya Ensafi was selected for the Sloan Research Fellowship.
Diwen Xue placed first in the University of Michigan CSE Honors Competition with his talk on measuring network interference.
Our work “OpenVPN is Open to VPN Fingerprinting” won First Place of the 2022 Internet Defense Prize and a Distinguished Paper award in Usenix Security 2022.

tools.name: CenAnalysis
tools.tagline: Pipeline for transforming raw Censored Planet Observatory data into structured BigQuery tables.

tools.name: CenFuzz
tools.tagline: Tool for fuzzing HTTP/HTTPS requests to uncover censorship rules and trigger conditions.

tools.name: CenTrace
tools.tagline: Application-layer censorship traceroute tool using TTL-limited HTTP and TLS packets to locate censorship infrastructure.

tools.name: CenProbe
tools.tagline: Set of scripts for actively probing and collecting data about particular network devices, including those that perform censorship.

tools.name: GeoInspector
tools.tagline: Measurement tool for detecting geoblocking and server-side blocking across DNS, TCP, TLS, and HTTP protocols.

tools.name: ZeroTrace
tools.tagline: Go package implementing the 0trace technique to estimate network-layer RTT using TTL-limited segments in existing TCP connections.

tools.name: AppMap
tools.tagline: Scripts for collecting Google Play metadata, APKs, and associated privacy policies.

tools.name: DNSBlockpage
tools.tagline: Tools for generating DNS blockpage fingerprints and analyzing Satellite v2 censorship data.
